facts.text: Petitioners Amar Singh and four others are displaced persons who owned land in Chak No. 159-RB, Tahsil Jaranwala, District Lyallpur in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: All these five are displaced persons who owned land in the number-suburban village of Chak. No. 159-RB, Tahsil Jaranwala, District Lyallpur in Pakistan.

facts.text: Petitioners were co-sharers in a joint khata owned by some evacuees in village Sultanwind, a suburb of Amritsar in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: They were also companysharers in a joint khata owned by some evacuees in village Sultanwind, a suburb of Amritsar in East Punjab.

facts.text: Petitioners were temporarily allotted agricultural land in Sultanwind.

anchor.surface_text: On their displacement, they were in the first instance temporarily allotted agricultural land in Sultanwind.

facts.text: In 1949, petitioners allotted 38 standard acres and 13 units of agricultural land in Sultanwind.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to their original position in the village, they were allotted in the year 1949 a total area of 38 standard acres and 13 units of agricultural land therein.

facts.text: Director-General of Relief and Rehabilitation Additional Custodian ordered on January 7, 1950, allotment of 142 standard acres and 5 units of suburban land of Amritsar to allottees of Provincial Gardens.

anchor.surface_text: The Director-General of Relief and Rehabilitation  Additional Custodian  directed by an order dated January 7, 1950, that out of the 1,263 standard acres and 1 3/4 units of suburban land of Amritsar, 142 standard acres and 5 units were to be allotted to allottees of Provincial Gardens.

facts.text: This necessitated readjustment of allotments of suburban land of Sultanwind.

anchor.surface_text: This necessitated readjustment of allotments of the suburban land of Sultanwind amongst the various groups who had quasi-permanent allotment therein.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian, Amritsar ordered on July 31, 1951, proposal for cancellation of petitioners' allotment.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this readjustment which had to be carried out according to certain rules and instructions, the allotment of these five petitioners  as also of some others  was proposed for cancellation by the order of the Deputy Custodian, Amritsar, dated July 31, 1951.

facts.text: Proposal approved by Custodian Financial Commissioner, Relief and Rehabilitation on February 6, 1952, and allotment cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: This proposal was approved by the Custodian  Financial Commissioner, Relief and Rehabilitation  on February 6, 1952, and the allotment was cancelled.

facts.text: Proposal and order of cancellation passed without notice to petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The proposal and the order of cancellation are said to have been passed without numberice to the petitioners.

facts.text: Petitioners moved Custodian-General for revision under s. 27 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved thereby they moved the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property for revision thereof under s. 27 of the Administration of Evancuee Property Act, 1950  XXXI of 1950 .

facts.text: Deputy Custodian-General dismissed revision on May 1, 1954, after hearing parties.

anchor.surface_text: This was dealt with by the Deputy Custodian-General who dismissed the same by a fairly elaborate order dated May 1, 1954, after hearing the parties.

facts.text: Petitioners filed application under Art. 32 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners have companye up to this Court by this application under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioners claim quasi-permanent allotment constitutes property rights violated by cancellation orders under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1), 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners is that the allotment to them was on quasi-permanent basis and that, therefore, they have acquired certain rights in the lands which companystitute property. They urge that the order of the Custodian canceling the allotment and that of the Deputy Custodian-General affirming the same are in violation of their fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19 1  f , 31 1  and 31 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: It is not disputed that petitioners are allottees on quasi-permanent basis.

anchor.surface_text: That the petitioners are allottees of agricultural land on the basis of what has companye to be known as quasi-permanent allotment is number disputed.

facts.text: Cancellation was under powers in Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 and rules.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that cancellation thereof was under the purported exercise of powers vested in the Custodian under certain provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  XXXI of 1950  and the rules framed thereunder taken with some executive instructions.

facts.text: Partition of India on August 15, 1947, accompanied by mass migrations of about five million Non-Muslims from West Punjab to East Punjab and Muslims vice versa.

anchor.surface_text: The Declaration of Independence and the partition of India into Pakistan and India on August 15, 1947, was accompanied by mass migrations of Non-Muslims from West Punjab to East Punjab and of Muslims from East Punjab to West Punjab. These mass migrations were on a stupendous scale. About five million persons are said to have moved from each side to the other.

facts.text: Displaced persons left about 67 lakh acres in Pakistan; evacuees left about 47 lakh acres in East Punjab and Pepsu.

anchor.surface_text: The displaced persons are said to have left in Pakistan lands of the extent of about 67 lakh acres. The evacuees sum to have left in East Punjab and Pepsu, lands of the extent of about 47 lakh acres.

facts.text: East Punjab Government Press Communique dated February 7, 1948, announced quasi-permanent allotment policy.

anchor.surface_text: This policy was announced by type Government of East Punjab in its Press Communique dated February 7, 1948, which is reproduced at pages 28 and 29 of the Resettlement Manual.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the petition holding quasi-permanent allotment does not constitute property under fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: For all the above reasons we are unable to hold that any fundamental right of the petitioners has been infringed. This petition is accordingly dismissed but, in the circumstances, without companyts.

facts.text: Petitioners have not obtained sanad under Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the learned companynsel for the petitioners that the petitioners in this case have number yet been able to obtain any sanad under these rules for the lands originally allotted to them and cancelled by the impugned orders of the Custodian and the Deputy Custodian-General.

anchor.surface_text: whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation fundamental rights companysemplated by the above articles. Both these questions require a review of the Evacuee Property Law

anchor.surface_text: They urge that the order of the Custodian canceling the allotment and that of the Deputy Custodian-General affirming the same are in violation of their fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1), and 31(2)

issues.text: whether the cancellation of quasi-permanent allotment constitutes deprivation of property without authority of law under Article 31(1)

anchor.surface_text: In any case it is clear that in order that Art. 31(1) may apply, it is not enough that there is deprivation but it must also be deprivation without the authority of law. What has happened, however, in this case is not deprivation of the property without the authority of law even assuming that the bundle of rights constituting such an interest in land is property.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners is that the allotment to them was on quasi-permanent basis and that, therefore, they have acquired certain rights in the lands which constitute property. They urge that the order of the Custodian canceling the allotment and that of the Deputy Custodian-General affirming the same are in violation of their fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19 1  f , 31 1  and 31 2  of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Interest of quasi-permanent allottee does not constitute property within the meaning of Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1), 31(2); provisional nature subject to cancellation powers under evacuee property laws

arguments.court_reasoning: Cancellation is under authority of law as incident of the rights created by the same law; ss. 28 and 46 bar challenge

court_response_anchor.surface_text: so, the words taking possession or acquisition in Art. 31 2  prior to the amendment are wholly inapt and inapplicable to the bundle of rights of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Totality of bundle of rights not property; mere possession not on higher footing for fundamental rights protection

court_response_anchor.surface_text: be so regulated from time to time and had an element of unstability, though they were being progressively invested with the characteristics of stabili

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle has no application as benefits under s.10 subject to cancellation powers under s.19 and r.102

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as happened, however, in this case is number deprivation of the property without the authority of law even assuming that the bundle of rights companys

arguments.court_reasoning: Such provisions have no bearing on whether interest constitutes property for fundamental rights protection

arguments.claim: All evacuee property vests in Custodian under s.8 AEP Act 1950; Custodian has powers under s.10 to manage including allotments and s.12(1) to cancel

anchor.surface_text: All property declared as evacuee property becomes vested in the Custodian under s. 8. The Custodian has under s. 10 the power to take possession ... This is subject to the power vested in him under s. 12 1 to vary or cancel leases or allotments of evacuee property.

arguments.claim: Quasi-permanent allotment defined as grant of right of use or occupation, originally temporary, subject to cancellation

anchor.surface_text: allotment is defined as meaning the grant by a person duly authorised of a right of use or occupation of an immovable evacuee property to any other person but does number include a grant by way of a lease.

arguments.claim: Rules on allotments including July 8, 1949 notification must be read to harmonise with cancellation powers under the Act

anchor.surface_text: according to the ordinary rules of construction, be read so as to harmonise with the powers of cancellation under the Act itself.

arguments.claim: Incidents of quasi-permanent allotment (use, heritability, improvements, etc.) subject to wide cancellation powers on administrative grounds

anchor.surface_text: His rights in the allotment are subject to the fairly extensive powers of cancellation under the Act and rules ... That it is necessary or expedient to cancel or vary the terms of an allotment for the implementation of resettlement schemes

arguments.claim: No sanad issued under DPCR Rules 1955 which grants permanent ownership; until sanad, no property right

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted ... that the petitioners ... have number yet been able to obtain any sanad under these rules for the lands originally allotted to them and cancelled by the impugned orders

arguments.claim: Under DPCR Act 1954 s.10, allottee continues possession post-acquisition but subject to variation/cancellation under s.19 and r.102

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 is important and provides inter alia that where any immovable property has been allotted ... the displaced person shall ... companytinue in possession ... subject to any rules ... the managing officer ... may cancel any allotment

arguments.claim: Interest of quasi-permanent allottee not capable of acquisition/disposal; hence not property under Art. 19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: Property, to fall within the scope of Art. 19 1 f , must be capable of being the subject-matter of acquisition and disposal. The interest of the quasi-permanent allottee ... is number capable of acquisition by the ordinary citizen

arguments.claim: Cancellation under authority of law that created the rights; ss.28,46 make orders final and bar jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 provides that orders made under the above sections shall be final ... Section 46 bars the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue courts

arguments.claim: Quasi-permanent interest analogous to jus in re aliena; provisional due to historical/administrative exigencies, not full property

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that cancellation thereof was under the purported exercise of powers vested in the Custodian under certain provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 ... At best it is analogous to what is called jus in re aliena

arguments.claim: Julius principle inapplicable as powers of cancellation continue post-acquisition

anchor.surface_text: This principle, however, has number application in the present case. While it is true that under s. 10 an allottee ... such benefits are subject to the powers exercisable under s. 19 of the same Act and r. 102

arguments.claim: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. State of Punjab incorrect on quasi-permanent interest being protected property

anchor.surface_text: a recent decision of the Punjab High Court reported in Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab ... we are unable to agree with the view expressed therein that a quasi-permanent allottee has such an interest ... as to constitute property

holdings.text: The interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is not property within the concept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2) of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evolution of evacuee property laws shows allotments are provisional grants of use/occupation, subject to wide cancellation powers under ss.8,10,12 AEP Act 1950 and rules; analogous to jus in re aliena; heritability and improvements do not elevate to property.

holdings.text: The interest of the quasi-permanent allottee does not fall within the scope of Article 19(1)(f) as it is not capable of being the subject-matter of acquisition and disposal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory incidents limit transfer (no sale, mortgage, gift); restricted to displaced persons; not alienable in normal modes.

holdings.text: Cancellation of quasi-permanent allotment does not constitute acquisition or taking possession under Article 31(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bundle of rights not equivalent to ownership transfer or possession right protected; words 'acquisition' or 'taking possession' inapplicable pre/post amendment.

holdings.text: Cancellation of allotment is not deprivation of property without authority of law under Article 31(1); it is pursuant to powers under the law creating the rights.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cancellation under ss.12,28,46 AEP Act 1950; authority of law that granted allotment; finality bars challenge; readjustment per administrative scheme.

holdings.text: No fundamental right of the petitioners has been infringed by the orders of cancellation; petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For all the above reasons we are unable to hold that any fundamental right of the petitioners has been infringed. This petition is accordingly dismissed but, in the circumstances, without costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of evacuee laws, provisional nature, no property rights violated under Arts.19(1)(f),31.

holdings.text: The Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford principle has no application to discretionary powers under s.10 DPCR Act 1954 and r.72(2) as benefits subject to cancellation under s.19 and r.102.

anchor.surface_text: This principle, however, has no application in the present case. While it is true that under s. 10 an allottee under the quasi-permanent allotment scheme has the benefit of continuing in possession thereof and may obtain transfer on application, such benefits are subject to the powers exercisable under s. 19 of the same Act and r. 102.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-acquisition powers to cancel persist despite continuation of possession; not indefeasible right to transfer/sanad.

holdings.text: Quasi-permanent allottee acquires permanent property only upon issuance of sanad under DPCR Rules 1955; prior interest not property.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the learned counsel for the petitioners that the petitioners in this case have not yet been able to obtain any sanad under these rules for the lands originally allotted to them and cancelled by the impugned orders of the Custodian and the Deputy Custodian-General.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanad culmination of scheme; until issued, no permanent ownership despite quasi-permanent possession.

holdings.text: View in Suraj Parkash Kapur v. State of Punjab that quasi-permanent interest constitutes protected property not accepted.

anchor.surface_text: But, with respect, we are unable to agree with the view expressed therein that a quasi-permanent allottee has such an interest in the land allotted to him as to constitute property, if it is meant to convey thereby that it is property which attracts the protection of fundamental rights under the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conflicts with analysis of statutory incidents and provisional nature under evacuee laws.

precedents.citation: Dunichand Hakim v. Deputy Commissioner  Deputy Custodian, Evacuee Property , Karnal 1954 S.C.R. 578

anchor.surface_text: In Dunichand Hakim v. Deputy Commissioner  Deputy Custodian, Evacuee Property , Karnal 1954 S.C.R. 578, this book has been referred to by this Court as having the stamp of authority. It can be usefully referred to not necessarily as an authority for every statement of fact or law contained therein but as a guide to appreciate the background of the problems which the administration had to face in that unprecedented situation

precedents.case_name: Dunichand Hakim v. Deputy Commissioner Deputy Custodian, Evacuee Property, Karnal
precedents.cited_proposition: Resettlement Manual referred to by this Court as having the stamp of authority

precedents.citation: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose 1954 S.C.R. 587, 673

anchor.surface_text: He relies on the judgment of one of us reported in the State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose 1954 S.C.R. 587, 673, where it was stated as follows The word property as used in Article 31(1) may have been intended to be understood in a wider sense and deprivation of any individual right out of a bundle of rights constituting concrete property may be deprivation of property which would require the authority of law.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: deprivation of any individual right out of a bundle of rights constituting concrete property may be deprivation of property which would require the authority of law under Article 31(1)
precedents.cited_holding: The word property as used in Article 31(1) may have been intended to be understood in a wider sense and deprivation of any individual right out of a bundle of rights constituting concrete property may be deprivation of property which would require the authority of law.

precedents.citation: Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford  1880  5 App. Cas. 214

anchor.surface_text: as laid down in the case in Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford  1880  5 App. Cas. 214. This principle, however, has no application in the present case. While it is true that under s. 10 an allottee under the quasi-permanent allotment scheme has the benefit of continuing in possession thereof and may obtain transfer on application, such benefits are subject to the powers exercisable under s. 19 of the same Act and r. 102 of the rules framed thereunder.

precedents.case_name: Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford
precedents.cited_proposition: where a discretionary power is vested in a statutory authority to act in certain circumstances for the benefit of certain persons, the exercise of such power in favour of such a person where requisite conditions exist is obligatory and not optional

precedents.citation: Bishop of Oxfords case  1880  5 App. Cas. 214

anchor.surface_text: Hence he has no such right to obtain a transfer which can be given effect to within the principle of Bishop of Oxfords case  1880  5 App. Cas. 214. He does not, therefore, appear to have an indefeasible right to obtain transfer of the very land of which he is the quasi-permanent allottee, if such land is acquired under s. 12 of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: principle that exercise of discretionary power is obligatory where conditions exist

precedents.citation: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab  1957  LIX P.L.R. 103

anchor.surface_text: After the close of the arguments before us a recent decision of the Punjab High Court reported in Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab  1957  LIX P.L.R. 103 has been brought to our notice and we have given our careful consideration to the same. That decision may be right on its merits, a matter about which we express no opinion.

precedents.case_name: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: quasi-permanent allottee has such an interest in the land allotted to him as to constitute property attracting protection of fundamental rights under the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This petition is accordingly dismissed but, in the circumstances, without costs. In holding that quasi-permanent allotment does number carry with it a fundamental right to property under the Constitution we are number to be supposed as denying or weakening the scope of the rights of the allottee.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Article 32 dismissed; no infringement of fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2); without costs
